Speaker: british announcer
Dialogue: Reports are coming in from all over the Empire -- from all over the world. The Government have not yet issued a statement, but there seems to be no question that there actually is a large, unidentified object circling the earth at incredible speed.

Speaker: american announcer
Dialogue: We still don't know what it is or where it's from - but we do know there's something there. It's been tracked around the world by radar traveling at a rate of four thousand miles an hour.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: They're here! They're here!

Speaker: brigadier general
Dialogue: Get me the Chief of Staff.

Speaker: governmental official
Dialogue: I want to speak to the President.  I'm sorry -- you'll have to interrupt him.

Speaker: pearson
Dialogue: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, this is Drew Pearson. We bring you this special radio-television broadcast to give you the latest information on the landing of the "space ship" in Washington.

Speaker: pearson
Dialogue: Government and Defense Department officials are concerned by reports of panic in several large Eastern cities. I am authorized to assure you that so far there is no reasonable cause for alarm. The rumors of invading armies and mass destruction are based on hysteria and are absolutely false. I repeat -- these rumors are absolutely false!

Speaker: pearson
Dialogue: The ship, designed for travel outside the earth's atmosphere, landed in Washington today at 3:47 p.m., Eastern Standard Time. We still don't know where it came from, but I can reveal that military leaders are considering two possibilities; that it came from some unfriendly power here on earth -- or that it actually arrived from another planet.

Speaker: pearson's voice
Dialogue: The ship is resting exactly where it landed two hours ago, and there has been no sign of life from inside it.

Speaker: pearson's voice
Dialogue: Troops have been rushed from Fort Myer and they have formed a cordon around the ship.

Speaker: pearson's voice
Dialogue: They are supported by machine guns, tanks and artillery.

Speaker: pearson's voice
Dialogue: Behind police lines, there is a large crowd of curiosity seekers.

Speaker: pearson's voice
Dialogue: As you can see for yourself, the Army has taken every precaution to meet whatever the situation may require. Every eye -- every weapon -- is trained on the ship. It's been this way for two hours and the tension--

Speaker: pearson
Dialogue: Just a minute, ladies and gentlemen! I think I see something moving!

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We have come to visit you in peace -- and with good will.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Gort! Deglet ovrosco!

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It was a gift. For your President.  With this he could have studied life on other planets.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Is he all right?

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Send for an ambulance. Get him to Walter Reed Hospital right away.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: How is he?

Speaker: major white
Dialogue: He's all right, General... Blood pressure's a little high, but it could be aggravation.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Can't blame him. I always get mad when somebody shoots me.

Speaker: major white
Dialogue: He still wants to see the President.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: We informed the White House over an hour ago.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Didn't drop any hints about where he's from, did he?

Speaker: major white
Dialogue: No, sir, he didn't.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Excuse me.  What about the reporters, Colonel? They're swarming all over the lobby.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Tell them there won't be any statement tonight.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Yes, sir.  Mr. Harley's here from the White House.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: General --

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Right in there, Mr. Harley.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: My name is Harley -- Secretary to the President  I've been told that you speak our language -- that your name is Mr. Klaatu.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Just Klaatu.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: The President asked me to convey his deepest apologies for what has happened. We all feel--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Sit down, Mr. Harley.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I'm sure I don't have to point out that your arrival was something of a surprise.  Had you been traveling long?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: About five months -- your months.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: You must have come a long way.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: About 250 million of your miles.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Naturally we're very curious to know where it is you come from.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: From another planet. Let's just say that we're neighbors.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: It's rather difficult for us to think of another planet as a neighbor.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'm afraid, in the present situation you'll have to learn to think that way.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: The present situation?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I mean the reasons for my coming here.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: We're very curious about that, too. Would you care to talk about it?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'd be glad to.  Not now, of course -- with you alone.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Perhaps you'd rather discuss it personally with the President--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: This is not a personal matter, Mr. Harley. It concerns all the people on your planet.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I -- I'm not sure I understand--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I want to meet with representatives from all the nations of the Earth.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I'm afraid that would be a little awkward. It's -- it's completely without precedent. And there are practical considerations -- the time involved -- the enormous distances.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I traveled 250 million miles. What about your United Nations?

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: You know about the United Nations?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We've been monitoring your radio broadcasts for a good many years. That's how we learned your languages. Lately, we've been getting your television also.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: You must have a rather strange impression of us.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: The first two years of television we were convinced that all you did was wrestle.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I'm sure you recognize from our broad- casts the evil forces that have produced the tension in our world. Surely you would agree--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I am not concerned, Mr. Harley, with the internal affairs of your planet. I consider that to be your business -- not mine.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I was only hoping to make you understand.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: My mission here is not to solve your petty squabbles. It concerns the existence of every last creature who lives on Earth.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Perhaps if you could explain a little--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I intend to explain. To all the nations -- simultaneously.  How do we proceed, Mr. Harley?

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: We could call a special meeting of the General Assembly... But of course the UN doesn't represent all of the nations.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Then why not a meeting of all the Chiefs of State?

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Believe me, you don't understand. They wouldn't sit down at the same table.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I don't want to resort to threats, Mr. Harley. I simply tell you bluntly that the future of your planet is at stake... I suggest you transmit that message to the nations of the Earth.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I will make that recommendation to the President.  I must tell you in all honesty that I'm extremely dubious about the results.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Apparently I'm not as cynical about Earth's people as you are.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I've been dealing in Earth's politics a good deal longer than you have.  Goodnight, sir.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Getting any place, Sergeant?

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Beats me, General. I saw that ramp come out of the side of the ship -- right here. Now I can't even find a crack!

Speaker: general
Dialogue: What's the report, Carlson?

Speaker: carlson
Dialogue: We've tried everything from a blowtorch to a diamond drill.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: What about him?

Speaker: carlson
Dialogue: He's made out of the same stuff.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Has he moved?

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: No sir. Not an inch

Speaker: carlson
Dialogue: This is the toughest material I ever saw, General. For hardness and strength, it's out of this world.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: I can tell you officially - that's where it came from.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: The skeletal structure is completely normal.  Same for the major organs - heart, liver, spleen, kidneys.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: And the lungs are the same as ours. Must mean a similar atmosphere -- similar pressure.  How old do you think he is?

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Oh, I'd say forty-five.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: He told me this morning when I examined him. He's seventy-eight.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: I don't believe it.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Their life expectancy is a hundred and thirty.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: How does he explain that?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: He says their medicine is that much more advanced.  He was very nice about it. But he made me feel like a third-class witch doctor.

Speaker: major white
Dialogue: I took a bullet out of that man's arm yesterday.

Speaker: first major
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: major white
Dialogue: I just examined the wound and it's all healed.

Speaker: first major
Dialogue: What does he say about it?

Speaker: major white
Dialogue: Said he put some salve on it -- some stuff he had with him.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: What are you going to do with it?

Speaker: major white
Dialogue: Take it downstairs and have it analyzed.  Then I don't know whether I'll just get drunk or give up the practice of medicine.

Speaker: first major
Dialogue: Afternoon, Mr. Harley.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Afternoon, gentlemen.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Good afternoon.  I'm glad to see you up and around.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Thank you... Have you any news?

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Not very good news, I'm afraid.  Well -- there you have it.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I tried to make you understand. The suspicions -- the jealousies -- the mistrust--  Surely you realize that my government has done everything in its power--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It's not your government I'm thinking about. It's your world.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Now that you understand the situation more clearly, perhaps you'd like to discuss the matter with the President

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I don't intend to add my contribution to your childish jealousies and suspicions.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Our problems are very complex, Mr. Klaatu. You mustn't judge us too harshly.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I can judge only by what I see.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Your impatience is quite understandable.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I am impatient with stupidity. My people have learned to live without it.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I'm very sorry -- I wish it were otherwise.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Before making any decisions, I think I should get out among your people -- become familiar with the basis for these strange, unreasoning attitudes.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: Under the circumstances I'm afraid that will be impossible.

Speaker: harley
Dialogue: I must ask that you don't attempt to leave the hospital. Our military people have insisted on this. I'm sure you'll understand.

Speaker: radio voices
Dialogue: --authorities at Walter Reed Hospital refused to comment on how he managed to escape, or what measures might be taken to apprehend him.

Speaker: television commentator
Dialogue: --while the President made no effort to minimize the crisis, he urged people all over the country to remain calm. He said the entire facilities of FBI and other federal agencies are being bought to bear. He pointed out, however, that this is no ordinary man hunt. He warned we may be up against powers that are beyond our control.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hey, Mom -- who's that?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: My name is Carpenter. I'm looking for a room.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Are you an FBI man?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: No -- I'm afraid not.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Bet he is, Mom. Bet he's out looking for that space man.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I think we've all been hearing too much about "space men."

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Can I help you look for the space man? Can I?  I know what he looks like! He's got a square head -- and, three great big eyes!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: That's enough, Bobby. I think it's time you went to bed.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: How did you know?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: This space man -- or whatever he is. We automatically assume he's a menace... Maybe he isn't at all.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Maybe he's afraid.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: After all, he was shot the moment he landed here.  I was just wondering what I would do.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Perhaps before deciding on a course of action, you'd want to know more about the people here -- to orient yourself in a strange environment.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: A person from another planet might disagree with you.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I must admit I'm a little confused.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Oh -- thank you.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We're all set. I picked up some sandwiches and put gas in the car. And the radio's still busted, so me can forget about the space man for today.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I don't suppose we could take him with us?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, we could--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: There's always somebody here, but today of course they've all got plans.

Speaker: klaatu's voice
Dialogue: I haven't any plans.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'd be glad to spend the day with him -- if you'd let me.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Say, that'll be great! Wouldn't it, Helen.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm sorry Mr. Carpenter -- this is Tom Stevens.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Bobby and I had a fine time yesterday afternoon. We talked -- and listened to the radio.  I thought today he might show me around the city.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Suppose I ask Bobby how he feels about it.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: He must have been a great man.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: That's the kind of man I'd like to talk to.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Bobby -- who's the greatest man in America today?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee -- I don't know... The space man, I guess.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I was speaking of earth men. I meant the greatest philosopher -- the greatest thinker.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Yes -- that would do nicely.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well -- Professor Barnhardt, I guess. He's the greatest scientist in the world.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: He lives here in Washington, doesn't he?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sure. Right near where my mother works.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Where is that?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Department of Commerce. She's a secretary.  Mr. Carpenter -- now can we go see the space ship?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Boy, I'll bet he's strong. I bet he could knock down a whole building.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I shouldn't be at all surprised.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee, I'd like to get inside and see how it works. What do you think makes it go?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Well -- atomic power, I would imagine.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I thought that was only for bombs.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: No. It's for a lot of other things, too.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You think it can go faster than an F- 36?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Yes -- I think so.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: About a thousand miles an hour?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Maybe four thousand miles an hour. And outside the Earth's atmosphere a good deal faster.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee! How could they make a landing?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Well -- there are several ways to reduce landing speed. You see, the velocity--

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Keep goin', Mister. He was fallin' for it.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You think they'll ever find him?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I don't know, Bobby. I'm inclined to doubt it.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Mr. Carpenter -- what does velocity mean?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Velocity is the time rate of change of position.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'll bet that's the way Professor Barnhardt talks.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Bobby -- I have an idea. Let's go see Professor Barnhardt and find out how he talks.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You're just kidding, aren't you?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Wouldn't you like to meet him?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, sure I would, but --  Aw, I'll bet you'd be scared.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We can scare him more than he can scare us.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I like you, Mr. Carpenter. You're a real screwball.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee -- maybe he isn't home.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Betcha this is where he works--

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It's a problem in celestial mechanics.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Bet he's the only one in the world knows the answer.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: He doesn't know the answer. And he'll never get it that way.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: We probably couldn't get to see him even if he was home.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hey -- where you going?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: If he's that difficult to see, perhaps we ought to leave a calling card.

Speaker: hilda's voice
Dialogue: What are you doing in here?

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: Do you realize the Professor has been working on that problem for weeks?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: He'll catch on to it in no time now.

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: How did you get in here? And what do you want?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We came to see Professor Barnhardt.

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: Well, he's not here. And he won't be back till this evening.  I think you'd better leave now. Unruffled, Klaatu turns to the desk and scribbles something on a scratch pad. He tears off the piece of paper and hands it to Hilda.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: You might keep this.  I think the professor will want to get in touch with me.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I wouldn't erase that. The Professor needs it very badly.

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: --no, Sergeant, there was no classified material around, but I have instructions to report anything unusual to the police... Yes -- I'm Professor Barnhardt's secretary.  The man's name is Carpenter -- and he lives at 1615 St. Street, N.W... Yes, that's right--

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's my father.  He was killed at a place called Anzio.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Did all these people die in wars?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sure. Didn't you ever hear of Arlington Cemetery?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: No -- I'm afraid not.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Mr. Carpenter" -- you don't seem to know about anything.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'll tell you, Bobby -- I've been away for a long time. Very far away.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Is it different where you've been?  Don't they have places like this?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: They have cemeteries. But not like this one... You see, they don't have any wars.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee -- that's a good idea.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: What would you like to do this afternoon?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Go to the movies.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No foolin'? Will you?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Certainly.  Tell me, Bobby -- do you have to have money to go there?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I've got some money. My mother gave me two dollars.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: No -- I want to take you to the movies.  Do you think they'd accept these?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee -- those look like diamonds!

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Some places that's what people use for money. They're easy to carry -- and they don't wear out.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Bet they're worth about a million dollars.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Would you give me your two dollars for a couple of them?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, sure, but--

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Let's not say anything to my mother about this, Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Why not, Bobby?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: She doesn't like me to steal from people.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Mr. Carpenter come home yet?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah -- he's right inside.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Tell him I'd like to see him.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Come on in.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Your name Carpenter?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Oh -- I suppose Professor Barnhardt's looking far me.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: I been looking for you all afternoon.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: It was a wonderful day.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You still haven't answered my question.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You know how I feel, Tom. I just want to think it over.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: The boss is leaving for Chicago tomorrow. If I could tell him I was getting married -- with two dependents--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You're a good salesman -- but I've got to think about it.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: A good insurance salesman wouldn't give you time to think.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: 'Night.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hi Mom!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Hello, darling.  Good evening, Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Mrs. Benson -- this is Mr. Brady.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Mr. Brady's a cop.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Did you have a nice day, dear?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Boy, we had a swell time. Didn't we, Mr. Carpenter?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We certainly did.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: We went to the movies -- and we had ice cream cones -- and we went to see Daddy--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I don't know how to thank you.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I enjoyed every minute of it.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: We better get goin', Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Aw, gee -- we didn't finish our story.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We'll finish it tomorrow... Goodnight, Bobby.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Goodnight.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Come on, Bobby. Time to go to bed.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Mom -- why does Mr. Carpenter have to go down to the police station?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I -- I don't know, dear... Perhaps there's some mistake.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: We sure had fun today. We saw the space ship and we went to see Professor Barnhardt -- and--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Professor Barnhardt.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, sure. Mom, do I have to go to school tomorrow?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Of course, dear.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Aw, gee, Mom -- I had plans to play with Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: first cop
Dialogue: B.M. Alberts -- no prior arrests.

Speaker: businessman
Dialogue: My wife just arrived with my identification.

Speaker: third cop
Dialogue: That'll be all, Mr. Baxter. Sorry to bother you... Next.

Speaker: fourth cop
Dialogue: Cappo, John C?  Two priors -- one for petty theft -- one for shoplifting.

Speaker: fifth cop
Dialogue: Okay, Jonny -- you can go.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: The Professor's secretary says she found you in Barnhardt's room, making marks on his blackboard.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I was only trying to be helpful. He was having difficulty with a problem.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Oh, I see. He was having trouble and you were helping him out.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: I suppose you know that Barnhardt does a lot of secret work for the Army.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: In this case the secret wouldn't be worth much. He doesn't know the answer himself.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: But I suppose you know the answer.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It's really quite simple... The three- body problem, you know.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Your name's Carpenter -- that right?  Any identification, Mr. Carpenter? Driver's license -- social security number?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: No -- I'm afraid not.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Well, how do I know who you are?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: You don't.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Excuse me, Lieutenant --  The Doc says this man needs treatment right away.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: What's the story?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Some fella caught him lookin' in a window and figured he was the space man. The whole neighborhood went crazy and they ganged up on him. Would have killed him if we hadn't come along... Turns out he was just a prowler.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Okay -- book him and get him fixed up.  Looks like everybody's goin' nuts.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: They would have killed this man?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Look, Mr. Carpenter -- if you can't identify yourself, I got to send you over to the Army.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: How long will that take?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: They can tell right away. They've got a couple of doctors who saw this man in the hospital.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It's very important, Lieutenant, that I see Professor Barnhardt.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: Come on, Mr. Carpenter--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: May I suggest that you call the Professor?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Get going, will you, Brady -- before I get mad!

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: The Captain here's got orders from General Cutler to take this man over to Professor Barnhardt.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Sorry to trouble you, Lieutenant.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Thank you, Captain.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: You wrote this?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I thought you'd have the solution by this time.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Not yet. That's why I wanted to see you.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: All you have to do now is substitute this expression--  --at this point.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Yes -- that will reproduce the first- order terms. But what about the effect of the other terms?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Almost negligible... With variation of parameters, this is the answer.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: How can you be so sure? Have you tested this theory?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I understand you've called a meeting to study our space ship.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: As though unsure of what he's heard) Yes -- yes, I have.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: My name is Klaatu.  If you are not interested -- or if you intend to turn me over to your Army -- we needn't waste any more time.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: You can go now, Captain. Please thank General Cutler and tell him -- tell him that I know this gentleman.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: You have faith, Professor Barnhardt

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: It isn't faith that makes good science, Mr. Klaatu. Its curiosity.  Sit down, please. I have several thousand questions to ask you.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I would like to explain something of my mission here.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: That was my first question.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We know from scientific observation that you have discovered a rudimentary kind of atomic energy. We also know that you are experimenting with rockets.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Yes -- that is true.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: In the hands of a mature civilization, these would not be considered weapons of aggression. But in the hands of your people--  We've observed your aggressive tendencies, and we don't trust you with such power.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: If you mean that you are afraid of us--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: So long as you were limited to fighting among yourselves -- with your primitive tanks and planes -- we were unconcerned. But soon you will apply atomic energy to space ships -- and then you become a threat to the peace and security of other planets. That, of course, we cannot tolerate.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: These other planets -- do they have peace and security?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We had our atomic wars -- thousands of years ago.  After that we fought with bows and arrows. Then, slowly, we learned that fighting is no solution -- that aggression leads to chaos.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: What exactly is the nature of your mission, Mr. Klaatu?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I came here to warn you that, by threatening danger, your planet faces danger -- very grave danger. I am prepared, however, to offer a solution.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Would you care to be more specific?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It is too important to be entrusted to any individual.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: I gather that your efforts on the official level were not entirely successful.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Must I take drastic action in order to get a hearing?

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: What -- what sort of action do you mean?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Violent action -- since that seems to be the only thing you people understand.  Leveling the island of Manhattan, perhaps -- or dropping the Rock of Gibraltar into the sea.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Would you be willing to meet with the group of scientists I am calling together?. Perhaps you could explain your mission to them, and they in turn could present it to their various peoples.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: That's what I came to see you about.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: It is not enough to have men of science. We scientists are too easily ignored -- or misunderstood. We must get important men from every field. Educators -- philosophers -- church leaders -- men of vision and imagination -- the finest minds in the world.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I leave that in your hands.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: You'd have no objection to revealing yourself at this meeting?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: No -- not at all.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: What about your personal safety in the meantime? What about the Army -- and the police?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: My name is Carpenter and I'm a very earthy character living in a respectable boarding house.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: I'm afraid I can't offer you any real protection. I have no influence in cases of inter-planetary conspiracy.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'm sure I'll be quite safe until the meeting.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: One thing, Mr. Klaatu. Suppose this group should reject your proposals. What is the alternative?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: --eliminated.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Such power exists?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I assure you such power exists.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: The people who came to the meeting must be made to realize this. They must understand what is at stake.  You mentioned a demonstration of force--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Would such, a demonstration be possible before the meeting?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Yes -- of course.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Something that would dramatize for them and for their people the seriousness of the situation. Something that would affect the entire planet.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: That can easily be arranged.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: I wouldn't want you to harm anybody -- or destroy anything.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Why don't you leave it to me? I'll think of something.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Maybe a little demonstration.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Would day after tomorrow be all right? Say about noon?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Yes, I'm waiting for Tom to pick me up.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Everyone seems so--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Jittery is the word.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Bobby's the only person I know who isn't -- Jittery.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He has his homework to keep him occupied.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: He's a fine boy, Mrs. Benson.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Naturally I think so.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Warm and friendly and intelligent--  You know -- he's the only real friend I've made since I've been here.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Mr. Carpenter -- this is none of my business, but -- why did that detective come here last night?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Oh -- they just wanted to ask me a few questions. Bobby and I tried to see Professor Barnhardt in the afternoon, but he wasn't in. Apparently they thought I was looking for secrets of some kind.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Hello--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You ready?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I will be in just a minute.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: The picture starts at eight-fifty.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I was talking to Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I hope Mr. Carpenter won't think I'm intruding.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Excuse me. I was just going up to my room.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Goodnight, Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Have a good time -- both of you.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Why don't you wait in here while I get my things?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Oh, Tom, that was awful.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't like the way he's attached himself to you and Bobby. After all, what do you know about him?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'll go get my things.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: All you have to remember is, first find the common denominator -- then subtract.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Thanks, Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'll say goodnight again.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Mr. Carpenter, I--  Goodnight.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Goodnight, my dear.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Go to bed, darling. You can finish that in the morning.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Bobby -- I think it would be better if we didn't see quite so much of Mr. Carpenter

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee, why, Mom? He's my best friend... And he's awful good in arithmetic. He even helps Professor Barnhardt.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Did you and Mr. Carpenter really go to see Professor Barnhardt?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sure we did! He wasn't there but we went to see him. And Mr. Carpenter showed him how to do his arithmetic.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Mom -- is there something wrong with Mr. Carpenter?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: What do you mean, dear?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I mean -- on account of that policeman last night.  You think he's a bank robber, maybe? Or a gangster?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: No, dear, of course not. He's a very nice man. I Just think he might prefer to be left alone. Now you get to bed and forget about it.  'Night, darling.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Goodnight.  Hey Mom -- why would he want to be alone?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Bobby -- have you a flashlight?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: It's a real Boy Scout flashlight.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What do you want it for, Mr. Carpenter?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Thank you, Bobby. Goodnight.

Speaker: helen's voice
Dialogue: Why don't you come on in for a minute?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Bobby--! What are you doing up at this hour?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I couldn't go to sleep, Mom. I had to tell you!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Tell me what?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I followed Mr. Carpenter -- right after you left -- and, gee, Mom, where do you think he went? Right into the space ship!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Now, Bobby, just a minute--

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Honest, Mom, I saw him. It just opened up and he walked right in. And that great big iron man was moving around!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Bobby, you've been dreaming again.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, I haven't, Mom. I promise you... I saw it!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Where did you see all this, Bobby?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: On the lawn down at the mall -- in that place with the soldiers out front.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Where were the soldiers all this time?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That robot fella grabbed 'em and dragged 'em inside!  I like Mr. Carpenter -- but I'm scared, Mom.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: The room right opposite mine.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Now think back hard. You didn't follow Mr. Carpenter at all, did you? You haven't even been out of the house.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yes, I have!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You didn't really see the space ship. You just thought you did.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'd never call you a liar.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: He's not there.  But look what I found in his room

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Is it real?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Looks real to me.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Mr. Carpenter's got a lot of diamonds.  He gave me a couple of them.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He gave these to you?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, not exactly. I gave him two dollars.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: This doesn't make sense... I think the guy's a crook. I never did trust him.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Gee, Mom, do you think maybe he's a diamond smuggler?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Come on, darling -- we're going up to bed.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I wonder if we ought to--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Bobby and I have had enough excitement for tonight.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You think it's all right for you to stay here?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: And Bobby's going to sleep in my room tonight.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Oh, boy -- can I, Mom?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Yes, dear. Come on now.  Bobby, your shoes are soaking!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah -- the grass was kind of wet.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Oh -- hello--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: May I see you for a minute?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I -- I was Just going to lunch.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: May I walk out with you?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Oh, hello...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm at Bleeker's getting an appraisal on that diamond. I thought we might have lunch together.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I -- I'm afraid I can't -- not right now. Can I talk to you later?. Yes, that'll be fine. 'Bye.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I saw Bobby this morning before he went to school--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Yes--?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I want to know what he told you last night.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Bobby has such an active imagination.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I have a reason for asking this -- a very important reason.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: There's another elevator we can use--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: What is it you want?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Before I ask you to be honest with me, perhaps I should be completely honest with you--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: What time is it?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Just twelve.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We'll be stuck here for a little while -- about thirty minutes.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I have a flashlight in my purse.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It won't work.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: You see -- the electricity's been neutralized -- all over the world.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Bobby was telling the truth -- wasn't he?

Speaker: cab driver
Dialogue: My ol' lady was right. We shoulda got a place in the country.

Speaker: cockney
Dialogue: It's that space man -- that's wot it is.

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: You should see it, Professor Barnhardt! You should go out and see it for yourself!

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Thanks -- I'm enjoying it right here.

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: The whole city has stopped. People are running around like ants!

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: What a brilliant idea. I never would have thought of it.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: What about the people who are coming to the meeting tonight? Have they all arrived?

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: I talked to most of them this morning... They were all very curious about the meeting.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Good. Did you speak to our friend Mr. Carpenter?

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Tell me, Hilda -- does all this frighten you -- does it make you feel insecure?

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: Yes, sir -- it certainly does!

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: That's good, Hilda. I'm glad.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: --as far as we can tell, all power's been cut off everywhere -- with a few exceptions: hospitals, planes in flight -- that sort of thing. I wish I could be more specific but, as you now, all communications are out telephone, radio, cable -- everything.  Before we start discussing plans, I want a report from Colonel Ryder. What about the robot, Colonel?

Speaker: colonel ryder
Dialogue: When it was discovered last night that the robot had moved, I was directed by the Joint Chiefs to find a means of immobilizing him. We accomplished that this morning by encasing him in a block of KL 93.  It's a new plastic material -- stronger than steel.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Is it possible that he's broken out of this stuff?

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: No, sir. I've Just checked on that. He's locked up tight as a drum.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: All right -- that means we concentrate on the man.  Is that clear?

Speaker: jeweler
Dialogue: Eleanor, did you call the electrician?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I tried, Mr. Bleeker. But the phone doesn't work, either.

Speaker: jeweler
Dialogue: Well, call the phone company.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: But the phone doesn't work.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Is it worth anything?

Speaker: jeweler
Dialogue: I have never seen such a stone. Will you please tell me where it came from?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's what I wanted you to tell me.

Speaker: jeweler
Dialogue: There are no diamonds like this -- any place in the world.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You sure about that?

Speaker: jeweler
Dialogue: Would you like to sell it?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No -- no, thanks.

Speaker: jeweler
Dialogue: I'd give you a very good price.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: --I've already told you more than I told Professor Barnhardt, because my life, in a sense, is in your hands. I thought if you knew the facts you'd appreciate the importance of my not being -- apprehended, -- before the meeting tonight.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Yes, of course. Of course I do.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You hold great hope for this meeting.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I can see no other hope for your planet. If the meeting should fail, then I'm afraid there is no hope.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: It must be twelve-thirty.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Yes -- Just exactly.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Where are you going now?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Back to the boardinghouse. I'll be safe there for the afternoon -- and I can keep an eye on Bobby. He's the only other person who knows anything about--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: No, wait a minute -- there's someone else.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Tom... He was there last night when Bobby told me what he saw.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: We can't take that chance. I'll get in touch with him right away and make sure.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: --But I've got to talk to him. It's terribly important. When is he coming back?

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: I don't know, Mrs. Benson. He left before noon -- before that awful electric business. I'm scared to death, Mrs. Benson. I -- No, he wouldn't tell me where he was gong. Said it was something personal.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Tell him I want to see him the minute he gets in... No, I'll call back.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Attention, please.... All flights from National Airport have been canceled until further notice.. All flights from this airport have been canceled.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: 'Bye now.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Call the Pentagon and find out who's in charge of this space man business. Whoever it is I want to talk to him.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Mrs. Benson's been trying to get you all afternoon. She says it's important.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Get this other call first.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Oh, Mrs. Benson -- He just walked in.  Are you nervous, too?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Yes, I am, Margaret.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Mrs. Benson is here.  Go on in.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Tom -- I've been trying to get you all afternoon--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Come on in.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I've got some terrific news about your friend, Mr. Carpenter.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: What about him?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Helen, he's the man from the space ship!  I had that diamond checked at three different places. Nobody on earth's ever seen a stone like that! After what Bobby told us, that's enough for me. Why is it nobody knows anything about him? Why hasn't he got any money?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: All right, Tom -- it's true. I know it's true.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Never mind about that.  You've got to promise me you won't say a word to anybody.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Are you crazy? After what happened today?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You don't understand. You don't realize how important it is.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Important? Of course it's important. The point is we can do something about it.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: That's what I'm trying to tell you. We mustn't do anything about it. Believe me, Tom, I know what I'm talking about.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: He's a menace to the whole world! It's our duty to turn him in.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: But he isn't a menace! He told me what he came here for.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You realize what this'd mean for us? I'd be the biggest man in the country. I could write my own ticket.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Is that what you're thinking about?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Why not? Somebody's got to get rid of him.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm not going to let you do it, Tom.  Believe me, this is literally the most important thing in the world.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: All right, I'll hold on.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Tom, you mustn't -- ! You don't know what you're doing! It isn't just you and Mr. Carpenter. The rest of the world, is involved!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I don't care about the rest of the world!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You'll feel different when you see my picture in the papers.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I feel different right now.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You wait and see. You're going to marry a big hero!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm not going to marry anybody.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, I don't want to speak to his aide. I want to speak to the General. Tell him it's about the space man... My name is Tom Stevens. S-t-e-v-e-n- s.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's right, General. That's where he's staying... Yes, of course I'm sure.

Speaker: general cutler
Dialogue: Deploy all Zone 5 units according to Plan B -- immediately.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Attention, Zone 5... Yellow cab, moving north on B from Ninth Street. Man and woman in back seat. Get the license number and report.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'm sure Barnhardt can arrange to hide me until the meeting.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Where is the meeting going to be?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: At the ship.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Attention, Zone 5... license number of target vehicle is W 4936... All vehicles maintain your positions -- and hold your fire.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Attention, Zone 5 -- report when target vehicle passes your position.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: It's only a few blocks to Barnhardt's.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'm worried about Gort. I'm afraid of what he might do -- if anything should happen to me.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Gort?  But he's a robot. I mean -- without you, what could he do?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: If anything should happen to me, you must go to Gort. You must give him this message: "Klaatu barada nikto." Please repeat that.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: "Klaatu barada nikto."

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Remember those words.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Attention, Zone 5... Section number 2 -- block off Tenth Street at Massachusetts. All vehicles close in.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Hey, what's this all about?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Get that message to Gort. Right away--

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Gort--!  Klaatu -- barada -- nikto.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: Yes, sir, we've got the body here now. Downstairs in a cell... No question about it, General -- he's dead all right... Yes, sir. Yes -- I understand.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: General Cutler's coming down here right away.  Captain, don't let anyone in or out of the building.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I -- I thought you were--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I was.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You mean he has the power of life and death?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: No -- that is a power reserved to the Almighty Spirit.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: This technique, in certain cases, can re-stimulate life for a limited period. It's a refinement of scientific principles known to your own people.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: But how -- how long--?

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: How long will I live?  That no one can say.

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Professor Barnhardt -- I have to ask you to call off this meeting.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Call it off? I... But I had permission from the Army--

Speaker: colonel
Dialogue: I know you did. But the robots on the loose now and it isn't safe around here. You'll have to get your friends out of that building.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Gort and I will be leaving soon.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He won't have anyone to play with.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: He'll have you -- and Tom.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: No. That's all finished.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I think I'm very lucky. You don't always get a chance to recognize a mistake before you make it.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: Ladies and Gentlemen--

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: I called you from your work and from your homes all over the world because we were to meet here tonight with a man from another planet -- the man who came here in this ship.  As you all know, this is no longer possible. I can only say that I share the bitterness of your disappointment.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Gort -- berengo.

Speaker: barnhardt
Dialogue: --under the circumstances, the Army people have asked us to leave the building. And, since their concern is for our safety, I can do nothing but suggest that we comply--

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: The Universe grows smaller every day -- and the threat of aggression by any group -- anywhere -- can no longer be tolerated.

Speaker: klaatu's voice
Dialogue: There must be security for all -- or no one is secure... This does not mean giving up any freedom except the freedom to act irresponsibly.

Speaker: klaatu's voice
Dialogue: Your ancestors knew this when they made laws to govern themselves -- and hired policemen to enforce them.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: We of the other planets have long accepted this principle. We have an organization for the mutual protection of all planets -- and for the complete elimination of aggression. A sort of United Nations on the Planetary level... The test of any such higher authority, of course, is the police force that supports it. For our policemen, we created a race of robots--  Their function is to patrol the planets -- in space ships like this one -- and preserve the peace. In matters of aggression we have given them absolute power over us.

Speaker: klaatu's voice
Dialogue: At the first sign of violence they act automatically against the aggressor. And the penalty for provoking their action is too terrible to risk.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: The result is that we live in peace, without arms or armies, secure in the knowledge that we are free from aggression and war -- free to pursue more profitable enterprises.  I came here to give you the facts. It is no concern of ours how you run your own planet -- but if you threaten to extend your violence, this Earth of yours will be reduced to a burned- out cinder.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Your choice is simple. Join us and live in peace. Or pursue your present course -- and face obliteration.  We will be waiting for your answer. decision rests with you.

Speaker: klaatu
Dialogue: Gort -- veracto.
